title: Life Cycle Stage of Monarch Butterfly

questions.questionText: What evidence do you see that tells you one butterfly has already emerged?

rubric.exceeds: Student identifies multiple specific details (brown color, empty appearance, clear window/opening) and explains how these features prove the butterfly left the chrysalis.
rubric.meets: Student correctly identifies that the brown chrysalis looks empty or has an opening, and connects this observation to the butterfly emerging.
rubric.approaching: Student notices the chrysalis looks different (brown or empty) but provides unclear or incomplete reasoning about what happened to the butterfly.
rubric.beginning: Student makes a vague observation about one chrysalis being different but does not clearly explain the connection to the butterfly emerging.

questions.questionText: Why might it be important for the chrysalis to be hard on the outside?

rubric.exceeds: Student explains that the hard shell protects the butterfly inside and identifies multiple reasons (from predators, weather, or damage) using specific details.
rubric.meets: Student explains that the hard outside protects the butterfly from predators or harm while it changes inside.
rubric.approaching: Student recognizes that protection is important but gives incomplete or vague reasoning about what the chrysalis protects against.
rubric.beginning: Student states the chrysalis is hard but does not explain why this matters or what it protects.

questions.questionText: How is a butterfly's life cycle similar to and different from a human's life cycle?

rubric.exceeds: Student identifies at least one similarity (both grow and change) and at least two differences (chrysalis stage, length of time, how they look), using specific details from butterfly development.
rubric.meets: Student identifies at least one similarity and one clear difference between butterfly and human life cycles with accurate explanations.
rubric.approaching: Student identifies either similarities or differences, but reasoning is incomplete or one part is unclear or inaccurate.
rubric.beginning: Student attempts comparison but provides mostly inaccurate or overly vague statements about life cycles.

questions.questionText: What do you predict will happen to the green chrysalis in the next few days?

rubric.exceeds: Student predicts the butterfly will emerge and explains the prediction using specific evidence from the photo (comparing to the empty chrysalis) and knowledge of metamorphosis.
rubric.meets: Student predicts a butterfly will emerge from the green chrysalis and provides a reasonable explanation based on the visible chrysalis or the other chrysalis in the photo.
rubric.approaching: Student predicts something will happen to the chrysalis but the explanation is incomplete or only partially based on observations.
rubric.beginning: Student makes a prediction but provides little or vague reasoning; prediction may be inaccurate or unclear.
